related-article.article-title: RETRACTION: Comparative Study of Wound Outcomes and Surgical Strategies: Internal Fixation Versus External Stabilization in Rib Fracture Patients with Traumatic Chest Wounds

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The clinical management of traumatic chest incisions accompanied by rib fractures presents the formidable challenge. The study was carried out to compare the outcomes of auscultatory triangle internal fixation (ATIF) and external fixation (EF) in such injuries. From June 2019 to June 2022, 105 patients with multiple rib fractures participated in the cohort study in which they were divided into two groups: 53 patients underwent ATIF and 52 patients underwent EF. The incidence of surgical site infection, wound healing time, incidence of wound dehiscence, number of dressing changes, pain as measured by the visual analogue scale (VAS), duration of hospitalization, period of return to work, pulmonary complications and functionality of the upper limbs as assessed by the Disability of Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH) questionnaire were among the parameters evaluated. In comparison with EF, ATIF demonstrated the decreased incidence of wound dehiscence (1.9% vs. 9.6%) (p < 0.05), surgical site infection (3.8 vs. 11.5) and wound healing time (12.3 ± 2.1 vs. 18.5 ± 3.7 days) (p < 0.05). Furthermore, during their ATIF treatment, patients required fewer changes of dressing (3.5 ± 0.8 vs. 5.7 ± 1.2) and demonstrated enhanced pain management, reduced hospital stays and expedited return to work (p < 0.05). ATIF group demonstrated enhancements in both upper limb functionality and post‐operative pulmonary function (p < 0.05). The utilization of ATIF as opposed to EF for the treatment of traumatic chest wounds accompanied by rib fractures yields superior outcomes in terms of wound healing, infection reduction and restoration of pulmonary and upper limb functionality.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In trauma care, the effective management of traumatic chest wounds accompanied by multi‐rib fractures is a formidable task due to the intricate balance that must be maintained between surgical intervention and conservative treatment in order to maximize patient outcomes and the complexity of the injuries. 1 Frequently caused by high‐energy impacts, these traumatic injuries can result in intricate fracture patterns, such as rib fractures, which are significant contributors to patient morbidity and mortality. 2 , 3 The clinical scenario is complicated by the existence of exposed wounds, which increases the importance of infection control, wound healing and pain management. These complications impose the substantial financial burden on healthcare systems and have particularly detrimental effect on the elderly, who have a higher risk of developing complications. 4 , 5

Rib fractures are not limited to skeletal injuries within the clinical environment; they can also cause substantial harm to soft tissues, especially when they are accompanied by traumatic chest wounds. These injuries manifest as sudden discomfort that is worsened by respiratory actions and have the potential to greatly hinder pulmonary function. As a result, careful attention must be paid to the management of both the laceration and the pain. 6 , 7 , 8 Rib fractures may manifest in various forms, varying in complexity from non‐displaced, uncomplicated patterns to displaced ones that may cause secondary trauma to underlying tissues and organs. A multimodal approach to pain relief, including systemic and regional analgesics, is frequently necessary to alleviate the intense pain associated with these fractures. 9 , 10 This is essential in order to mitigate the potential respiratory complications and promote the process of wound healing. 1

Standard imaging modalities, including computed tomography (CT) scans and chest x‐rays, are of the utmost importance in surgical planning and diagnosis, especially when it comes to determining the extent of rib displacement and related chest injuries. 9 , 10 Such injuries as pneumothorax, pulmonary contusions and thoracic haemorrhage have a substantial impact on the prognosis and course of treatment. 2

The optimal management of rib fractures in conjunction with concomitant chest wounds has been the subject of debates since the inception of surgical techniques. 11 , 12 , 13 , 14 , 15 , 16 , 17 External stabilization methods that provide support for the thoracic girdle are now being compared in terms of efficacy with internal fixation methods. 18 Internal fixation frequently employs minimally invasive techniques like the auscultatory triangle approach. Although both approaches share the common goal of stabilizing the fracture, reducing secondary trauma and facilitating wound healing, they each have unique ramifications in terms of long‐term outcomes and surgical complications. 19 , 20 , 21

This research endeavoured to perform a comparative evaluation of these surgical methodologies, determining how they affect the overall prognosis for patients who have traumatic chest wounds complicate rib fractures and secondary trauma to the wound site.

sec.title: Demographics and grouping of patients
sec.p: From June 2019 to June 2022, this cross‐sectional cohort of 105 patients presenting with multiple rib fractures was prospectively evaluated. The patients were divided into two distinct groups based on the treatment they received: Group A (consisting of 53 individuals) underwent internal fixation using the auscultatory triangle method, and Group B (consisting of 52 patients) was treated with sternal band external stabilization. The composition of the sample was gender‐neutral, consisting of 53 males and 52 females. Automobile collisions (n = 53), structural collapses (n = 4), high‐altitude falls (n = 17), electric bicycle accidents (n = 13), abrasions (n = 11) and machinery‐related compressions (n = 7) were the causes of the fractures. The cataloguing of rib fracture distribution revealed the following: 52 left‐sided cases, 45 right‐sided cases and 8 bilateral cases.

Group A (internal fixation) comprised 30 males and 23 females, the mean age of whom was 43.24 ± 4.57 years. The number of fractures exhibited variability, as 26 patients reported having no more than five rib fractures, while 27 patients surpassed that threshold. The calculated mean body mass index (BMI) was 21.32 ± 1.13 kg/m2. In Group B (external stabilization), there were 22 females and 30 males, with a mean age of 44.86 ± 5.08 years. In this setting, total of 23 patients experienced rib fractures, with 29 having a higher incidence at five. Mean BMI was recorded as 21.48 ± 1.2 kg/m2. There were no statistically significant distinctions identified in relation to fracture distribution, age, or gender between the two cohorts (p > 0.05).

sec.title: Criteria for inclusion and exclusion
sec.p: Participants who satisfied the subsequent inclusion criteria were deemed eligible: demonstration of minimum of three rib fractures, ascertained through 3D CT thoracic reconstruction, fractures primarily situated in the posterior thorax, capacity for spontaneous coughing and age below 70 years.

The exclusion criteria comprised participants in strenuous physical labour, fractures of the ribs that were exposed, severe pulmonary contusions resulting in hemopneumothorax and concurrent critical injuries.

sec.title: Fixation internally by means of the auscultatory triangle method
sec.p: The operation commenced 4–6 days after the injury with the implementation of static vacuum ventilation to both lungs and single‐lumen tracheal intubation under general anaesthesia. Prior to operation, fracture points and surgical site were marked. Along the auscultatory triangle, the longitudinal incision was performed, which was aligned perpendicular to the superior aspect of the latissimus dorsi muscle and maintained appropriate length to permit muscle retraction. In order to expose the rhomboids, latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior, intermuscular fascia was dissected. By mobilizing these muscles, access was gained to the rib fractures. Fractures were realigned utilizing vascular forceps or absorbent towels for manipulation, following periosteal elevation. Chosen rib supports made of nickel–titanium memory alloy based on the curvature and dimensions of the rib were submerged in sterile cold water. The fracture sites were then covered with these supports, which were fastened with heat to facilitate their deformation to the rib's contours. After internal fixation, metronidazole and alcohol gauze were utilized to irrigate and treat the wound. A drain was implanted through the chest tube, pleural effusions were aspirated and incision was closed with the drain in place.

sec.title: Sternal band external stabilization
sec.p: Group B patients were administered sternal band external fixation (EF) in conjunction with comprehensive post‐operative care encompassing sputum management, analgesia, haemostasis, analgesia and infection control.

sec.title: Assessment of pain
sec.p: Using the visual analogue scale (VAS), a standardized instrument for subjective pain assessment, the intensity of the pain was quantified. By ranging from 0 (indicating no pain) to 10 (indicating the worst conceivable pain), the VAS score permits comparisons between patients or assessments of pain progression (Figure 1).

sec.title: Hospitalization and disruption of work
sec.p: The hospital utilized average length of stay (ALOS) as the significant efficiency metric; shorter stays were indicative of possible cost reductions. The post‐discharge return to employment period was monitored by nursing follow‐up.

sec.title: Cumulative pulmonary disorders
sec.p: Following treatment, the incidence of pulmonary complications (atelectasis and lung infections) was monitored at 1‐week, 1‐month and 3‐month intervals.

sec.title: Tests of pulmonary function
sec.p: On post‐operative day seven and upon admission, pulmonary ventilation function was evaluated in comparison with forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1) and maximal voluntary ventilation (MVV).

sec.title: Functionality of the upper limb
sec.p: Upper limb function was assessed using the Disability of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH) questionnaire both before and after treatment. A larger degree of impairment was indicated by higher DASH scores.

sec.title: Wound healing assessment metrics
sec.p: Subsequent to the initial wound closure assessment on post‐operative days 1, 3 and 7, weekly evaluations of the wounds were performed. Where infection was suspected, wound cultures were obtained in order to direct the administration of targeted antibiotics.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The data analysis was conducted utilizing version 26.0 of SPSS software. Comparing categorical data required the χ 2 test, whereas t‐test was utilized to analyse continuous variables expressed as mean ± standard deviation. A p‐value less than 0.05 was deemed to indicate statistical significance (Table 1).

caption.p: Demographic data between internal fixation of triangular rib fractures and external fixation groups.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Consent having been obtained from all the participants, the research was carried out in adherence to the ethical guidelines set forth by the hospital.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Both cohorts of patients were observed 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery and were discharged from the hospital cured. The duration of distress exhibited statistically significant variations between the two groups (p < 0.01). The VAS in the internal fixation group was found to be superior to that of the EF group at 1 week and 1 month post‐operatively (p < 0.05). Nevertheless, no significant differences in VAS were observed at 3 months post‐operatively (p > 0.05) (Table 2). By employing the auscultation triangle approach, internal fixation group demonstrated significantly decreased work interruption periods and shortened hospital stays in comparison with the external thoracic girdle fixation group. The observed disparities were substantially statistically significant (p < 0.05) in particular, the internal fixation group returned to work and recovered considerably more quickly (p < 0.05). The improved efficacy of the internal fixation technique in promoting patient recuperation and resumption of regular activities was highlighted by these findings (Table 3). The incidence of pulmonary complications was comparatively lower in internal fixation group at 7‐day post‐operative mark: only 8 out of 53 patients (15.1%) experienced such complications, while EF group experienced 15 out of 52 patients (28.8%) (p < 0.05). Additional cases of secondary trauma were documented in nine cases (17.3%) of EF group and five cases (9.4%) of the internal fixation group. Although patients undergoing internal fixation had lower incidence of secondary trauma (p > 0.05), the incidence was non‐significant (Figure 2).

sec.p: Before initiation of treatment, DASH scores were comparable between the two patient groups, indicating no significant difference in upper limb function due to treatment modality chosen (p > 0.05). Following 3‐month post treatment, patients who underwent internal fixation demonstrated improved DASH scores, suggesting greater recovery of upper limb function compared with those who received EF (p < 0.05) (Figure 3). The post‐treatment MVV values of patients in both treatment groups (p < 0.05) improved significantly (Table 4). There was no significant difference in initial MVV values between the groups upon admission (p > 0.05). Conversely, patients who underwent surgical internal fixation demonstrated a statistically significant elevation in MVV on 7th post‐operative day (p < 0.05) in comparison with those who were treated with EF (Figure 4).

sec.p: The findings pertaining to the wound healing metrics indicated that substantial differences were evident in the outcomes. Significantly reduced in frequency, surgical site infection affected mere 3.8% of patients in internal fixation group, as opposed to 11.5% in EF group (p < 0.05). Internal fixation group exhibited the considerably shorter average lesion healing time compared with external (p < 0.05) as well as significantly reduced incidence (p < 0.05) of wound dehiscence (1.9% vs. 9.6%, respectively). Patients in internal fixation group experienced the reduced average time to wound closure (11 days), in contrast to 17 days required by patients in EF group (p < 0.05). Average number of dressing changes were also reduced (Table 5).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The high incidence of rib fractures in the domain of thoracic trauma presents a substantial clinical obstacle that necessitates a management strategy that not only attends to the immediate physical harm but also reduces the risk of life‐threatening complications including hypophora, circulatory insufficiency, hemopneumothorax and hypophora. 22 , 23 , 24 Conventional approaches to managing these injuries, which frequently involve chest wall suspension, compression bandaging and ventilatory support, are attracting growing scrutiny for their correlation with extended periods of recovery, severe pain, postponed disease progression and a variety of additional complications. 25 , 26 , 27 These complications may include permanent thoracic deformity and diminished pulmonary function.

The surgical treatment of rib fractures has undergone a paradigm shift as a result of the development and refinement of internal fixation instruments and techniques, which were initially developed to optimize clinical outcomes. Previously a laborious and highly intrusive process, the procedure has undergone significant development to become a less arduous and more streamlined intervention, gaining widespread approval in the medical communities of both the United States and abroad. 28 , 29 , 30 Traditional surgical techniques, including longitudinal, posterior or anterior incisions, have been the norm. Despite their efficacy, these methods may result in substantial muscle disruption and subsequent permanent disability of the affected limb. 31

In this research, we conducted the comparative analysis of the outcomes linked to two types of rib fracture fixation techniques: EF utilizing a thoracic girdle and internal fixation utilizing the auscultatory triangle method. Various factors were evaluated, such as the overall patient prognosis, secondary trauma and post‐operative complications. The results of our research have been exceptionally enlightening, revealing distinct benefits linked to the internal fixation method. The internal fixation method specifically exhibited a substantial decrease in VAS scores, suggesting that patients encountered a diminished intensity of pain. Additionally, this approach resulted in decreased durations of hospitalization and fewer disruptions to employment, both of which have substantial socioeconomic implications. 32 , 33

A significant disparity was observed in the post‐operative evaluation of pulmonary complications between the two cohorts of patients. The significant reduction in the occurrence of these complications within the group that underwent internal fixation suggests that the procedure successfully mitigated the likelihood of developing pulmonary sequelae. The internal fixation group exhibited a lower incidence of secondary trauma; nevertheless, this disparity failed to achieve statistical significance. 18 , 21

Furthermore, it was observed that patients' upper limb functionality was improved with both therapeutic approaches, as indicated by the enhancements in DASH scores. However, it is the group that underwent internal fixation that demonstrated significantly improved scores 3 months after the treatment, indicating that the improvements in limb function persisted. Furthermore, the MVV of patients who underwent internal fixation was significantly elevated on the seventh day following the operation, indicating a more rapid restoration of respiratory capacity.

When examining the technical intricacies of the auscultatory triangle technique, it becomes apparent that the region beneath the scapula has a lower density of muscle tissue. This characteristic provides an ideal environment for rib fixation, which can be extended further when the upper limb is elevated. This surgical technique presents numerous advantages: it is consistent with the well‐established protocols of open surgery, making it straightforward to implement; it also ensures improved post‐operative muscle function; and it entails a reduced risk of surgical complications, resulting in a less traumatic experience. 34

The auscultatory triangle demonstrated the benefit of internal rib fixation, specifically with regard to muscle preservation, as demonstrated by our research. This approach not only maintains the advantages of conventional open surgery, including adequate visual field and thorough haemostasis, but also substantially mitigates muscle damage. As a result, the probability of patients developing chronic post‐operative chest pain due to muscle scar contraction is reduced, allowing them to promptly resume their daily activities. In addition, the reconstructive characteristics of the procedure result in post‐operative pain that is of a shorter duration, facilitate the restoration of a functional cough reflex, minimize the loss of lung volume and reduce the likelihood of surgical‐related complications. 35

Ribs extending along the lateral thoracic wall from the third to the seventh are the most commonly fractured ribs anatomically, owing to their exposed and susceptible character. 36 The rib fractures extending to the second posterior rib can be accessed through the auscultatory triangle incision, which provides a strategic advantage by creating a tunnel‐like, horizontal space that facilitates thorough fracture exposure. As a result, the efficacy of the internal fixation procedure is subsequently improved. 37 Utilization of the four‐pronged rib splint, which has a maximum extension of 30 cm, is linked to a diminished likelihood of operative injury and facilitates an expedited restoration of functionality in the upper extremity of the patient. 38 Furthermore, the nickel–titanium alloy rib fracture internal fixators, characterized by their distinctive temperature‐memory property, provide significant operational simplicity and reduce the necessity for intrusion into the bone marrow cavity. 39 , 40

The wound healing outcomes were favourable in internal fixation, consistent with results reported in other studies that supported using minimally invasive surgical techniques. For example, researched indicated that minimally invasive procedures result in decreased rates of infection as consequence of reduced tissue trauma and smaller incisions. 41 , 42 , 43 The infection rate observed in the internal fixation group, stood at 3.8%, comparable to the infection rates documented in analogous settings, ranging from 1.8 to 8.9%. 44

The internal fixation method exhibits a significantly shorter average wound healing time of 12.3 days in comparison with conventional approaches, which have been documented to induce healing times exceeding 20 days. 45 The accelerated recovery can be ascribed to the diminished inflammatory response and reduced extent of soft tissue dissection that are characteristic features of minimally invasive procedures. 46

Notwithstanding these developments, it is crucial to recognize the relative constraints that arise in practical application when utilizing the auscultatory triangle incision. The effective implementation of this procedure requires an exceptional degree of surgical dexterity, considering the limited space for movement and the critical nature of controlling the intercostal vessels to avoid excessive haemorrhage. Furthermore, although this method is generally efficacious, it may not be universally applicable, particularly in situations that necessitate thorough investigation or when the fracture configuration hinders optimal visualization and manipulation via the incision.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The study provided evidence that auscultatory triangle internal fixation (ATIF) is more effective than EF when it comes to treatment of traumatic chest incisions accompanied by rib fractures. Significantly reduced rates of surgical site infection, accelerated wound healing, diminished wound dehiscence, hospital stay and recuperation time are all associated with ATIF. In addition, additional benefits of ATIF, as measured by DASH scores, include enhanced early post‐operative pain management, more rapid return to work and superior recovery of upper limb function. With ATIF, pulmonary function, as measured by post‐operative MVV values, also improved significantly. As a result of these findings, ATIF should be utilized preferentially in the clinical management of rib fractures resulting from traumatic thoracic injuries.
